title: Coronation Stone of Motecuhzoma II (Stone of the Five Suns)
alt_titles: Coronation Stone of Moctezuma II ("Stone of the Five Suns")

thumbnail.alt_text: Large plaque of stone carved with animal and geometric hieroglyphs.

description: This stone, commemorating the beginning of the reign of Emperor Motecuhzoma II, was originally located within the ritual center of Tenochtitlan, the capital of the extensive empire conquered by the Aztecs between 1428 and 1519. The ruins of the city lie beneath downtown Mexico City. Known as the Stone of the Five Suns, this monument draws connections between Aztec history and the cosmic scheme. The quadrangular block is carved with the hieroglyphic signs of five successive cosmic eras, called “suns” in the language of the Aztecs. These eras were mythic cycles of creation and destruction that began in the time of genesis and continued with the birth of humankind and the period of Aztec rule. From “4 Jaguar-sun” in the lower-right corner, the eras proceed counterclockwise through “4 Wind-sun,” “4 Rain-sun,” and “4 Water-sun.” The X carved in the center represents “4 Movement-sun,” the sign of the present era for the Aztecs. The year “11 Reed” in the square cartouche refers to 1503, the year of Motecuhzoma’s coronation, while the day listed above it—“1 Crocodile”—corresponds to July 15, when the ceremony probably occurred. On the underside, the hieroglyphic date “1 Rabbit” denotes the beginning of things in the distant mythological past. The sculpture thus legitimizes Motecuhzoma’s rule as part of the cycle of birth, death, and renewal and presents him as heir to the world in the present era of creation.
publication_history: H.B. Nicholson with Eloise Quiñones Keber, Art of Ancient Mexico: Treasures of Tenochtitlan, exh. cat. (Washington, DC: National Gallery of Art, 1983), 41–42. Richard F. Townsend, ed., The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, exh. cat. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1992), 58–59, 375. John McKay, A History of World Societies, 5th ed. (New York: Houghton Mifflin Company, 1999). Jean Sousa, Looking at Art Together: A Parent Guide (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2002). Art Institute of Chicago, The Art Institute of Chicago: The Essential Guide, revised ed. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2003), 15. Eduardo Matos Moctezuma and Felipe Solis Olguín, Aztecs, exh. cat. (London: Royal Academy of Arts, 2003), 455–456, cat. 226. Gauvin Bailey, Art of Colonial Latin America (New York: Phaidon Press, 2004). Eduardo Matos Moctezuma and Felipe Solis Olguín, The Aztec Calendar and other Solar Monuments, trans. H. J. Drake (México, D.F.: CONACULTA-Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia, Grupo Azabache, 2005), 125–126, 155. Art Institute of Chicago, The Essential Guide, revised ed. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2009), 24. Richard R. Townsend, The Aztecs, 3rd ed. (New York and London: Thames and Hudson, 2009), 29–30. Colin McEwan and Leonardo Lopez Lujan, eds. Moctezuma: Aztec Ruler, exh. cat. (London: British Museum, 2009), 68–69. Richard F. Townsend and Kathleen Bickford Berzock, “The Art Institute of Chicago New Galleries,” in Tribal Arts XVI-1/62 (Winter 2011): 65, fig. 15. Richard Townsend with Elizabeth Pope, Indian Art of the Americas at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago and Yale University Press, 2016), 234–235, cat. 186.
exhibition_history: Washington, DC, National Gallery of Art in association with Dumbarton Oaks, Art of Ancient Mexico: Treasures of Tenochtitlan, Sept. 28, 1983–Jan. 8, 1984, cat. Art Institute of Chicago, The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, Oct. 10, 1992–Jan. 3, 1993, cat. 3; Houston, Museum of Fine Arts, Feb. 4–Apr. 18, 1993; Los Angeles County Museum of Art, June 6–Aug. 15, 1993. London, Royal Academy of Arts, Aztecs, Nov. 16, 2002–Apr. 11, 2003, cat. 226; Berlin, Germany, Martin-Gropius-Bau, Kulturveranstaltungen des Bundes, May 16–Aug. 10, 2003; Bonn, Kunts-und Ausstellungshalle der Bundesrepublik Deutschland, Sept. 12, 2003–Jan. 11, 2004. Chicago, The Field Museum, The Aztec World, Oct. 28, 2008–April 19, 2009, not in cat. London, British Museum, Moctezuma: Aztec Ruler, Sept. 24, 2009-Jan. 24, 2010, cat. 14.
provenance_text: Stendahl Art Galleries, Los Angeles, by Feb. 10, 1971 [unpublished typewritten analytical study prepared by Hasso von Winning and sent to Stendahl Art Galleries on Feb. 10, 1971, inscribed “HvW Feb. 10, 1971” and “to Stendahl 10-II-71,” in the West Lake Society archive, RI; slide of object at Stendahl Art Galleries photographed by H.B. Nicholson identified as “5 Suns Stone,” marked “S” (referring to Stendahl Art Galleries), and timestamped with slide processing date FEB71H7, in the H.B. Nicholson Slide Archive, California State University, Los Angeles; copies in curatorial object file]; sold to Seth G. Atwood (1917–2010), Time Museum, Rockford, IL, Nov. 14, 1972 [letter from Patricia Atwood, Dec. 18, 1989; copy in curatorial object file]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, Jan. 9, 1990.
